I was born with severe asthma and an allergy to all things airborne. Pollen, dust, cockroach dander, cat dander - anything airborne, I was in for a Bad Time (tm). Yearly ER trips, multiple day hospital stays, medication, inhalers, ventilators, those misting drug machines I can't remember the name of ...

It was bad.

Then I moved to Georgia. One of the worst allergies I had was pine pollen. Even the scent of Pine-sol could cause my airways to close (might have been psychosomatic at that level but the point still stands). I had ONE bad asthma attack in GA the first year I was there - and then nothing. There could be clouds of yellow-green billowing from the streets and I could walk right through.

The ONLY thing I could think of was that my body was 'shocked' by the amount of pollen - so much so that the constant presence of the stuff caused the allergic reaction to eventually stop.

But that's just a guess. It could have been the trees were so different than the ones I grew up near that they triggered a psychosomatic asthma attack the first year but by the second, my mind was very much elsewhere. Except my cat allergy went mostly away (I can still get itchy eyes if I rub a cat literally in my face that I'm not used to but a few weeks later, same cat does nothing). My dust allergy is gone. I no longer need to fear cleaning behind the TV.

In light of the content of this video - where allergies are developed due to exposure - I'd like an explanation as to why mine went away with the same. Or MAYBE allergies are more complex than this video let on and over-exposure is just one way of gaining this anti-power.

There is currently a medication on the market pending FDA approval called AXS-05, which combines an Antihistamine with an antidepressant. It has very promising pre-clinical trial results and while it's approval has been stalled, the antihistamine it uses in particularly makes sense.

It's the same anti histamine that increases serotonin levels in the brain, that if taken improperly, could cause serotonin syndrome. Using it safely and properly dosed should prevent histamine from interfering with the antidepressant and has a synergistic relationship to it instead. Should this medication be approved, it'd be the most effective medication we've seen for depression treatment to date. It is hopefully coming out this very year, 2022. This could be history in the making. We'll just have to wait and see.

Bit surprising that they didn't mention first-generation antihistamines being insanely "dirty drugs". Most of them are also anticholinergic (lots of side effects), antidopaminergic (which is why a lot of antipsychotics were derived from first-gen antihistamines) and some are antiserotonergic (which is why some people experience relief from nausea while taking them).

The science they present in this video is solid, but it's just one aspect of a much larger story. Of course they can't cover everything in a 12 minute video, but it's a bit disappointing that they didn't even hint at the other aspects that are involved.

I think this might turn out to be a very important autism link. A great deal of autistic children have gut issues. It might also explain why vaccines don't appear to cause autism on population studies while many frustrated parents tell you otherwise: you'd have to have a predisposition to H2 and 3 overproduction before something that triggered an autoimmune response (such as a sudden increase in adjuvent in a newborn infant) triggered chronic histamine production. In other words, Autism isn't caused by vaccines but in sensitive individuals, all auto immune responses can tip them into an inflamed state that can later lead to autistic regression.
Combined with the fact that the most effective H2 and H3 blockers work through methylation and that gut issues lead to lower intrinsic factor, these individuals may have trouble absorbing B12 in their diet. When B12 stores run out, we may expect an accelerated decline into autism which explains the phenomenon of regression at 1 year.

As you pointed out, histamine is an incredibly important neurotransmitter in arousal. Like the catecholamine neurotransmitters, it contributes to wakefulness and focus in certain parts of the brain. Modafinil, a eugeroic drug, has histaminergic activity.

The fundamental point needs to be appreciated that there is no neurotransmitter that only does one thing. What they do is, in fact, arbitrary in the sense that the distribution of receptors constrains their actual function more than the structure of the particular neurotransmitter molecule itself.

Dopamine "increases motivation," but it also "causes compulsive gambling." More fundamentally, it "increases motor activity." But, it's peripheral activity on vascular tissue is distinct from all of those things.

Unfortunately, brains are really complicated. It's pretty much guessing and checking with psycopharmeceuticals, even at this point. But we're getting better.

Be careful taking antihistamines if you take medications for blood pressure control. Drug interactions are often poorly researched and little info is available to warn you of potential problems. Doctors also have little time to keep up with drug interactions, so you may need to try to be well informed yourself. Sometimes, controlling diet and exercise can affect how much medication you need and even whether making other changes in lifestyle can eliminate a need for a medication. Your kidneys and liver have to work hard to break down and eliminate drugs from your body, so take responsibility and be well informed and be the primary person managing your own health. If you live outside of the USA, you may have options for better health care in some countries. Personally, my healthcare experiences abroad were far superior to the healthcare I received in the USA.

Many people with Bipolar cannot take most antihistamines due to first-generation antihistamines triggering depressive symptoms, and non-drowsy antihistamines causing mania. The good news is that there are now antihistamines that are applied via nasal sprays that don't enter the bloodstream, meaning that the compounds don't reach the brain. Thus, people with bipolar can take antihistamine nasal sprays without fear of it destabilizing their mood. These nasal sprays are prescription-only, so consult your doctor if you think you might need one. Most of these nasal sprays also contain some type of steroid to treat the swelling associated with the nasal congestion that usually accompanies allergies. This increases the overall effectiveness of the nasal spray at treating allergies, but also means that these drugs need to be regulated more than other antihistamines.

This video contains a lot of misinformation as it took nearly everything that is known about these drugs and Histamine receptors out of context. Reading at least one actual paper on the subject (you know - like science communicators are supposed to do), could have avoided this!!

Most, if not all of the 1st generation antihistamines (Diphenhydramine, Hydroxizine) are so called "dirty drugs", meaning they unintentionally target many other structures next to the intended ones (the H1 receptors) in the body. I.e. Hydroxyzine (Vistiril) being well suited for treating anxiety and some withdrawl conditions results from it acting as a neuroleptic/antipsychotic (Dopamine D1/D2 antagonist) agent and Serotonin modulator (changing Serotonin levels in different areas of the brain via acting the presynaptic HT1-A autoreceptor feedback loop) for example. These beneficial therapeutic effects are not related to Histamine receptors at all.

There also are drugs classified as antidepressants or antipsychotics that do additionally act as antihistamines. Their antidepressant/antipsychotic action DOES NOT result from that antihistamine mechanism in any way, shape or form however. The only effects that Histamine antagonism/inverse agonism contributes in these cases are fatigue/sleepyness/tiredness, weight gain, constipation and ofc. reduction of allergy symptoms… These effects have been discovered and linked to the Histamine receptors by trying out "non-dirty" antihistamines that do not act on any other structures at all.

Thank you for doing a video on anti-histamines! Can there be a follow-up video on mast cells?

Mast cells play a crucial role in histamine production, as well as in releasing other inflammatory compounds (like leukotrienes). Overall, they’re a crucial part of the immune system that the general public knows little about.

Plus, there’s very interesting on-going research looking into potential links between mast cells/mast cell conditions, and COVID/“long”-COVID symptoms and disease severity! There’s also emerging evidence linking increased mast cell counts in intestinal tissue with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). And there’s still much, much more to be learned in how mast cells function and how they affect us!

I’m not an expert in this field, but I have been clinically diagnosed with Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS), among other chronic health conditions. It’s hard to explain to a lot of people because they don’t know what mast cells are, so I’ve had to at least learn enough to explain what my condition is, how it is currently understood to work, and how can MCAS present itself.

Between the general lack of knowledge in the public about them, despite playing a key role in immune system function and overall health, I hope @SciShow would consider making a future video dedicated to mast cells!

Fun story how I found out about how important histamines are in the body: I have a histamine intolerance, as well as ADHD and several allergies. I took mirtazapine for some time and wondered why my motion sickness was gone (I experienced it when I played 1st person games). I was baffled. After some research, I found that a) the trigger of motion sickness is too many histamines, b) vitamin c can help with combating symptoms and c) around 80% of the effects from mirtazapine actually come from blocking histamine receptors, which is why it is used as a sleeping aid (mostly off-label). From there on, I was intrigued. I contacted one of the professors researching histamine intolerance and he confirmed that mirtazapine can help with motion sickness. In his book he also described that deaths related to drug abuse often comes from anaphylaxis (too much histamine) triggered by the drug.

A fee years ago, I was admitted to the hospital because of heart palpitations. I was worried that I got some of the heart conditions that run in my family. Luckily, I was perfectly healthy, however, I was still experiencing palpitations. Turns out, palpitations can be a symptom of histamine intolerance and can be treated by giving high doses of antihistamines! Histamine intolerance has sooo many symptoms and it is so little known about.

It's so interesting and there is still so much to learn! By the way, motion sickness is a stress reaction and stress triggers the release of histamine from the mast cells, which is why vitamin c helps. It helps metabolizing the histamine!

Also, too much histamine in your body can trigger ADHD-like symptoms! It can also go the other way around: Suspiciously, a lot of autistic people have GI issues. I personally believe it comes from the realease of histamine because autistic people deal with a lot of stress in their lives. I wouldn't be surprised if the role of antihistamines in the treatment of psychological conditions gets bigger and more important in the future and as a psychology student I am really excited about it! I wouldn't be surprised if depression had a connection to the lack of histamines (for example).

A few more antihistamine facts I know off the top of my head: Antihistamines are also used to treat anxiety, in the case of hydroxyzine. Seroquel (quetiapine, antipsychotics) is a strong H1 antagonist among its many other effects on the brain, and it's believed to be a component of its method of action. On the topic of first generation vs second generation antihistamines, another important improvement they make was the limitation of anticholinergic side effects. These are the dry mouth, vasoconstriction, and very importantly, wild deliriant-type hallucinations caused by many first-generation antihistamines such as diphenhydramine (benadryl, many many other brand names). It's very interesting to me that diphenhydramine remains by far the most widely available of all the antihistamines even though it's known, almost notoriously so, for these side effects, and we have many other options with the same therapeutic index and fewer side effects.

I’ve been using Benadryl at bedtime for a couple years now. I don’t just do it for the sleep now, though it started like that. I noticed after I used it , my baseline anxiety and extreme negative emotion/maybe undiagnosed depression went way way down.

Now I’m not suicidal, and my anxiety wasn’t totally unmanageable, but I was diagnosed with ADD as a kid. I don’t take any stims for it. (Besides caffeine, which is pretty norma and safel.) The symptoms however are still there. Which include the anxiety/depression/extreme negative emotion generally. And cutting those down makes that a lot easier to manage.

Make no mistake, I should actually see a psychologist. And a regular doctor too. I don’t suggest self medication to anyone. But personally, I haven’t really been in a good financial place for insurance or meds. And the ADHD (Inattentive) makes it difficult to get too a place like that. So using the tools I have been given, I’ve been able to get more stable. And consider my next steps. And that for me, was diphenhydramine every night before bed. 100mg. That’s twice the dose for sleeping.

The L/D50 is something extraordinary like 10x to 20x that. The only thing that happens if you go much higher than 100mg is really horrendously bad trips for 8 hours. Or maybe you start talking about temporary psychosis at around 500mg. You pose more of a danger to yourself then, than the drug. Unless you mix it with something. Not that I’m suggesting it, and only to point out that it’s somewhat more difficult to do permanent damage from the drug itself. When compared to Tylenol or another highly toxic drug.

Anyway. I’m not surprised by this news is my point. I experienced it myself.
